Name: Walt Disney'n Aku Ankka -noppapeli
Description:
This game is a very simple and typical roll and move game, where players try to go from the beginning to the track which has 100 positions. In places where there's a red position instead of a yellow, players encounter different kinds of problems which may affect who's the winner.

Paletti game no. 2893

Name: Suuri tietopeli
Description:
In this game, the board is built of puzzle pieces at the beginning of the game. Each puzzle piece contains a question category. All the players use the same button, which is moved according to a die throw. The question is asked in the category of where the button gets to. There is also an extra category, which contains yes-no questions of all the categories.

This game seems to be a Finnish version of the game called "Geni!" (http://www.boardgamegeek.com/game/22289). This is written in the box cover too. However, there are some differences. For example, in the Finnish version there are 56 puzzle pieces instead of 15 in Geni!

Name: Kick-O-Mania
Description:
Kick-o-Mania is a dexterity soccer/football game played on a large 4x7 foot playing field.  The figures are fully positionable and controlled by your actions.

Rules and a full range of figures and game accessories are available in stores or through the website http://www.kick-o-mania.com

Name: Travel 2 Games
Description:
[Publisher]
Great on the road, at home, and every place in between. Travel fun for the whole family. 
Play I Spy, Road Sign Challenge, and more with 54 colorful cards!

[Submitter]
A collection of simple kid games suitable for playing at travel. 
(1) ROAD SIGN DOMINOES - a domino game using road sign paired cards.
(2) ROAD SIGN CHALLENGE - Looking around outside the car for the road sign pictured on card.
(3)I SPY - Looking around to spy the letter (from the drawn card) on license plates, billboards, signs or anywhere else.
(4) I SPY, TOO! - Looking for things that begin with the pictured letter.
(5) ALPHABET TRAVELER - Name a place that begins with the pictured letter.
(6) I'M GOING ON A TRIP... - Make a word chain using words that start with the pictured letter(s), and alternately repeating the word chain plus a new word.

Name: Dungeon Dwellers' Fantasy Boardgame
Description:
From the publisher:

An entirely new concept in the RPG-boardgame hybrid genre. A d20 based boardgame equally as usable as an occasional distraction or full fledged campaign.

Some features of the boardgame:

d20 ensures a familiar basis and a quality rules set 
32 page rule book containing 6 core races, 12 core classes, and 52 unique special abilities 
60 full color folding miniatures for your characters, usable for this boardgame or any other purpose 
A starter dungeon to get everything started, including full color maps and unique monsters with folding miniatures of their own
Beautiful illustrations by V. Shane, Sacrosanct Games, and Octavirate Entertainment

Name: Game, Set & Match
Description:
Game, Set & Match is a Tennis board game that uses a die and deck of cards for playing shots, and a board and pawn to show the position of the ball on court.
Players serve by rolling a die marked Ace/Let/In/Out, then if the ball is in play, cards are played for each shot of the rally that determine the stroke played and the position of the ball on the court. Singles or doubles can be played.

Name: Paths of Glory: Player's Guide
Description:
The Player's Guide contains articles that describe tips, tactics, strategies, and variants available for Paths of Glory. In addition to the 48-page magazine, the Player's Guide includes 20 new cards and a 1/4 sheet of additional counters.

Recent deluxe editions of the base game already contain the "optional counters first released in the POG Player’s Guide in 2002" and the "20 Optional Cards from the POG Player’s Guide".


(from GMT Games's website:)

Features
The Paths of Glory Player's Guide is designed as an expansion kit for your enjoyment of this wonderful game, with exciting and informative articles featuring strategies for you to employ, new scenarios and variants, new playing cards, in-depth analysis of key features in the game, and so much more. Executive Editor Wray Ferrell has put together an excellent team of authors and Managing Editor Stuart K. Tucker's handsome layout design makes reading and utilizing the Player's Guide a pleasure.

Contents and Authors

Strategy

    The Opening Guns (Peter P. Perla) - Learn the Giuco Sedano, Warsaw Waltz and Tarnopol Tango in this article that covers a myriad of the many ways to experience August 1914 in Paths of Glory.
    Goin' Mobile (Kris Weinschneker) - Play of the Mobilization deck involves some critical choices about War Status and Reinforcements.
    Limited War Cards (Kris Weinschneker) - Continuing his discussion of the card decks, Kris offers his suggestions on getting from "Limited" to "Total" war quickly.
    Total War Cards (Kris Weinschneker) - Wrapping up his review of the cards, Kris offers some endgame card play suggestions.


New Scenarios and Cards

    New Scenarios (Ted Raicer) - The game's designer provides the official starting setups, including card dispositions, for games begun in 1915, 1916, or 1917.
    Adding More Paths to Your Deck (Ted Raicer) - Twenty new cards are included as an insert to this magazine. Here are their historical bases.


Analysis

    PoG Supply (Ananda Gupta) - The disruption of supply lines can cause the collapse of a front. Each theater has a number of key locations in the defense of those vital supply lines.
    Parade of Fools: The Italian Front (Ananda Gupta) - The Italian front offers both promise and danger to both sides, as they attempt to overcome the foibles of their "weak sister" armies.
    Optional Rules: Assessing the Balance (Ananda Gupta) - How effective are the mainstream optional rules at establishing a balanced game?


Cybergaming

    PBEM Primer (Kris Weinschneker) - A primer on playing Paths of Glory via Play By Email.


Variants

    Variant Cards (Tod Reiser) - More card ideas to consider adding to your deck.
    Pre-War Options (Ted Raicer) - For those wanting to vary the starting force setup, here are some ideas for each major nation.
    Strategic Options (Rick D. Stuart) - Rick provides us with more options to alter game play - some affecting the setup, some used later in the game.
    Historical Variants (Brad Martin) - For those seeking to experiment with history and game balance, here are more variant rule ideas.

Name: Harpoon 4: Player's Handbook
Description:
From the Publisher´s web
The Harpoon Player's Handbook is a 28 page compilation of all the charts and tables contained in the rulebook. Use of this playing aid greatly assists the flow of play in multiple player games, as all of the data is right at hand, along with references to the appropriate section of the rulebook.


    The Harpoon Series


Expands

    Harpoon 4

Name: 2 Hour Test Cricket
Description: A solo game that enables players to play a complete Test Match in around two hours. You can add individual stats for players, but it adds around 25% to the time to play. A quick, easy and very flexible and exciting game. Perfect for cricket fans who want to play entire series without it becoming a life's work.

Name: Commerce
Description:
This game is from 1900 and was published by the J. Ottmann Litho Company of New York.

The directions say that Commerce is "the most amusing game on the market"

The game is comprised of a deck of cards with 8 suits
 (Pork, Sugar, Cotton, Corn, Coffee, Oats, Flour and Butter) of 6 cards in each suit, making 48 cards in all.

After shuffling the cards, deal each player 6 cards. Each player sorts the cards that they have and then decides which suit they will try to corner.

The object of the game is to obtain all of the cards of one suit by trading with other players.

To play you take from your hand a card or cards of similar suite and holding them up call "Trade 2 or trade 3. All players do that at the same time so there is lots of yelling going on. Sorta like what happens on the New York Stock Exchange. People make trades of cards. So you could trade 2 with someone else then find that the 2 that you receive match a card or two that you already have in your hand and now you might try and trade 3 for 3. When the first player succeeds in getting all of the cards in a suit the player calls "corner" shows the cards to everyone else. First player to get 3  corners wins!

Name: Shell Out
Description: The game is played on a hexagon board composed of 6 blue triangle fields known as Playing Fields. The Playing Fields are divided by rows of red playing spots running toward the center of the board known as Alleys. These Alleys may be traveled from one end to another in a single move if desired. In each game there are 30 shells divided into groups of 5, each group has a different  color. There are also 6 counters numbered 5,10,15,20,25 and 50. At the beginning each player draws a counter, looks at it and then places it beneath one of his shells so that no opponent knows under which shell the counter is.  . The object of the game is to move a shell into the SHELL OUT area of an opponent. You may attempt to capture a shell of your opponent. If you are next to a opponents shell you simply jump on it. Most shells have nothing under them and simply result in your losing your shell. If you find the shell with the scoring marker under it you score it. The hand is over when someone moves a loaded shell unto the opponents SHELL OUT area.

Name: The First World War
Description: Issue game of Command Magazine Japan #72, 20 Dec 2006, along with SS: Third Reich.

Name: SS: Third Reich
Description:
Issue game of Simulator #33, 25 April 1991.

Republished as an issue game of Command Magazine Japan #72, 20 Dec 2006, along with First World War.

"SS" means "Sugoroku-Simulation".

A multi-player game in which players play German generals fighting for the honor to be the first to reach Moscow.

Name: Blue
Description:
From the rules: Blue is from the series Factor-5 and is the first jigsaw in which you can compete against other players. You must quickly find suitable pieces to make the jigsaw and then swap the pieces which are the wrong color - you will be surprised by how many possibilities there are.

The game consists of 5 nearly identical jigsaw puzzles of 48 pieces each. There are multiple objects in the picture on the puzzle which are different on each board. All the pieces are then mixed together. Players race to complete the puzzle gaining points for first, second etc. In the second part of the game, players swap pieces to correct errors subtracting incorrect pieces from your score.

Name: Plomo y Salitre
Description:
Spanish ship-of-the-line game heavily based on Wooden Ships & Iron Men, but set as miniatures rules.

The period covers the Revolutionary and Napoleonic wars at sea and the rules have a complete list of ships available for play of different nations: Spain, Great Britain, France, Portugal, the Ottoman Empire, Russia, Sweden, Holland...

Also includes turns and fire templates for cut and use with the ships.

Home Page (Spanish): http://www.plomoysalitre.com

Name: Fortaleses
Description:
Fortaleses (Fortress) is a push-your-luck dice game, for 2-5 players.

The players try to build the strongest fortress, using dice towers, and they can, also, attack the fortress of the rest of players.

This game wins the 5th Creation Game Contest in the Fira JocJoc in Tona, Catalonia, Spain in 2006.

Name: Rat Race
Description:
Rat Race is a card game that is played as fast as possible, all players playing cards simultaneously.  Each player has a cheese card in a different maze material (stone, brick, wood, and metal).  The cheese card is at the bottom of each player's deck.  The rest of the cards are parts of a labyrinth made of the four materials.  Players flip over their cards and connect to the existing maze, placing their cards wherever possible.  The first player to connect his or her cheese card to the maze wins.

https://www.thegamecrafter.com/games/rat-race

Name: Achtung Panzer: Company Level Combat on the Eastern Front 1941-1945
Description: A company level game of World War II combat.  First in a new series by L2 Design group.  The first game includes four geomorphic maps, while other games in the planned series include one on Berlin 1945 and one on Stalingrad which will feature historical terrain.
Families: Players: Wargames with Rules Supporting Only Two Players

Name: Usgrächnet Bünzen
Description:
In this re-themed edition of Ausgerechnet Buxtehude, we are now trying to learn the geographical locations of cities and sights of Switzerland. In the swiss edition, there also cards with mountains.

Players place cards on the table according to their relative location. Other players may doubt the accuracy of the placement you made. Should the accusations turn out to be true, you would have to give out a scoring marker. The player with the most scoring markers in the end wins.

The game includes 200 location cards with longitude, latitude, and other information about locations.
As there are four languages spoken in Switzerland the rules are supplied also in those four languages (German, French, Italian  and Rhaeto-Romanic)

Name: Koalabröderna: På flygtur med Frank och Buster
Description:
Swedish children´s game themed on the Koala Brothers. Players are flying around trying to be the first to visit all their friends. Each player is given 4 tiles, each picturing one of the 9 friends. Up to 9 tiles per player can be used `for a more complex game´. Players roll the die and move on the square grid on the board, visiting squares where the friends are. Friends must be visited in the same order as the tiles in front of the player. Squares are either empty or have a picture of a friend or an airplane. The airplane shows the direction that players must leave that square. First player to visit all 4 (or more) friends is the winner.

Contents:
Game board
4 pawns
36 picture tiles
Die

5 years and up

Note: This game is not identical to Die Koala BrÃ¼der: Auf Geht's Nach Haus!(GameID: 21833).

Name: The Moose Spotting Game
Description: The object of the game is to get 20 or more Moose Spotting points.  All players should have the same number of turns before one is declared the champion Moose Spotter.

Name: Höjdarna
Description: Swedish children´s game themed on the TV-series Höjdarna. Roll the colored die and move towards the air balloon in the middle of the board. If you get the right cards you can move there quicker. Suddenly the balloon will take off. Will you be on board?

Name: Bä bä vita lamm
Description:
Swedish children´s game. The 36 wooden tiles each show either the front or the back of a lamb on a colored background, so that the tiles match up into 18 lambs with a red background, a green background etc. Players roll the die and turn up tiles. When two tiles match the player may take that lamb. There are black lambs to mess things up. If the die shows the picture of a lamb, the first player to sound like a lamb may take one lamb from any player. The player with the most lambs is the winner.

Contents:

36 wooden tiles
Die
Rules

Name: Alfons kortspel
Description:
Swedish card game featuring Alfons and friends from the books and short films by Gunilla Bergström. 58 cards are dealt equally among the players. One card is placed face-up on the table. The starting player turns up the top card from his deck. If it is the same character as the open card, or if the balloons on the cards are the same color, the player plays the card on a common pile and continues turning his cards. When the cards don´t match the player discards his card and the next player turns up his top card. If a player turns up a card that is both the same character and the same balloon color as the open card, he may put all his discards on the pile. Players may have to turn their discard pile into a new draw deck. The first player to run out of cards is the winner.

No decisions to make at all, but an easy game for small kids.

Name: The National Bicycle Game
Description: Early 20th century roll and move Bicycle race game.  The colorful board represents a 100 mile race. Published in Australia.

Name: Tour de France
Description:
A very different type of roll and move game.

The board has been replaced by two rolled paper bands in plastic boxes.  The Bikes with riders sit on top.

Dice are rolled to determine how far your rider goes, but instead of moving the rider across a board, you simply turn the rollers to advance the roll (which serves as the tracks).

Name: Nitty Gritty
Description:
Nitty Gritty: The Star Game

If you are an eager beaver, here's your chance to get even steven with any funny bunny, providing you don't get into double trouble in which case any hanky panky could become hairy scary.  So don't dilly dally, but get down to the nitty gritty so you can razzle dazzle without phoney baloney - and that, silly Billy, is super duper.  Does this sound like mumbo jumbo?  (From the box)

The game consists of 154 printed cards which, when properly matched with each other, make 77 pairs.  Pair examples are: Mellow Yellow / Roly Poly / Plain Jane / Hebbie Jebbies...etc.

Each of the 154 cards has one word and from one to three stars printed on the face of the card.  The number of stars indicates the value of the card.

The purpose of the game is to win as many matched pairs of cards as possible.  When the stockpile of cards is gone, the player with the greatest number of stars is the winner.

Name: Vier Länder Tour
Description: Roll and move bicycle race game set in the Alps. Austrian publisher.

Name: Hot Stove Pack 1
Description:
A scenario pack for Critical Hit's Advance Tobruk System (ATS).

The package contains two maps and 6 scenarios all covering actions on the Western Front in 1944.

Note that no rules and counters are provided so that ownership of other games in this system (e.g. Scottish Corridor) and/or spare countersheets obtainable from Critical Hit is required to play.

Expands

    Advanced Tobruk: Tank Battles in North Africa 1940-43
    Scottish Corridor: Lion Rampant

Name: Big Jim: Il Giro D'Italia
Description:
Bicycle race game from Mattel Italy.  Features dice that include results with fatigue, punctures and energy.

Has 2 2-sided boards for 4 different race courses

Name: Lootin' Wizards
Description:
From publisher's website:

After the death of the beloved Royal Mage of the kingdom, the king of the land set out a challenge to find his replacement. Wizards from far and wide came to vie for the position. As the challenge was set forth a few of the smarter and sneakier ones thought of a good way to get a leg up. They made their way into the secret dungeon of the former Royal Mage and decided to loot it for what they needed to win... But only one can win, so the battle for the loot began.

Lootin' Wizards is a fun group card/board game where you race around the randomly placed dungeon, trying to get more loot than your opponents. Make spells to battle each other, using the ingenious three card spell system (for thousands of possible creations). Screw up their spells with troublesome Side Effects. Foil them with entertaining Trap cards. Use helpful Items to aid your quest to grab all the Loot you can.

http://www.dragavangames.com/

Name: Conga
Description: Conga is a two-dimensional game which combines characteristics of Kalah games with four in a row. One players uses 10 black seeds, the other 10 white seeds. Players start with their cache of seeds in opposite corners of the board. The contents of a pit are distributed into the succeeding pits in a particular manner not unlike the "sowing" that happens in Mancala games. The object of the game is to form a row of four occupied holes (the colors of the seeds don't matter), diagonally or orthogonally. In addition, you win if your opponent can't move.

Name: Get Better Bear
Description: Play doctor and be the first to make the teddy bear better.  Move your character around the board, placing bandages on boo-boos as you go.  Watch out for gauzy shortcuts.  When you reach the lollipop, flip it over and put it on the bears mouth.  You made him smile and you win.

Name: Combination Board 4 Games
Description:
Combination Board, 4 Games (boxed):
Manufactured by Wilder Mfg. Co., St. Louis, MO., U.S.A., around 1920, before they carved up Germany and Austria-Hungary and created Poland, etc., because the map matches 1918 Europe.
This set of 4 games (designed for 2 to 4 players) in one box includes two folding game boards with a game on each side. The four games are: 1. Indian Home Game (looks and plays like Parcheesi); 2. Game Hunt (move around the board scoring points for shooting critters -- Rabbit = 1, Lion = 12); 3. Army and Navy (move around a map of WWI Europe, scoring points for capturing enemy officers and weapons -- Zeppelin = 1, Flag and General = 10); 4. Auto Race (race around a track, avoid obstacles, cross finish line 1st).

Contents: Two 12" x 12" mounted game boards with a different game on each side, 16 1/2-inch round wooden playing pieces (4 red, 4 yellow, 4 green, 4 blue), and 1D6 (wooden) in a 6.5" x 14" x 1.5" flat box. The rules for 3 games are inside the lid; the Auto Race game has the rules right on the board.

Name: Börja läsa
Description:
A game in Kärnan´s line of wooden games for children. This is an educational game to help children learn to read and write. The game features 77 wooden tiles with letters and 8 double-sided boards with pictures and some letters. Players connect tiles to make the words matching the picture on each line.

5 years and up.

Name: Rumble Robots Invasion
Description: Rumble Robots was a children's collectible card game sold in starter decks and booster packs circa 2001.  The premise is based around warring factions of sci-fi robots.  There are two sides: a blue team of good guys, and a red team of bad guys, each lead by a robot king.  The blue king is King El Smasho and the red king is King Slugnut.  The cards themselves are called Power Cards and contain bar codes for interaction with Rumble Robots toys.  Each card has a "power level" from 1-5 which corresponds to both its rarity and relative usefulness in the game.  In addition, there are "platinum" cards, more powerful than level 5 cards.  One expansion set was released, "Rumble Robots: Invasion", which focused on the two king characters as well as adding a further rarity level called "superpower" cards.

Name: Hold the Phone
Description: All players must hold hands to make Tommy the telephone talk.  Tommy tells you what picture to find by making silly sounds.  When Tommy says Time's Up, the person with the most discs wins.

Name: Snoopy Card Game
Description: The Snoopy Card Game board consists of eight popular Peanuts characters--Charlie Brown, Sally, Lucy, Schroeder, Peppermint Patty, Woodstock, Franklin and Linus. Players try to march along the paw-print path to the finish by matching cards from their hands with the characters on the board.  By collecting "scoring bowls" players move one, two, three or four spaces at a time.  Each round ends with players drawing a card from the player to their right.  Amongst the various character cards are eight "Snoopy Ha-Ha" cards which serve as dead spots in your hand since none of them can match the characters on the board.  First player to reach the finish is the winner.

Name: Med vilda gester
Description: Party game where players act out words and their teammates try to guess the word. Basically it´s charades, but you may make sounds and whistle tunes as long as you don´t use actual words.

Name: Scrambled Eggs
Description:
Each player tries to match the color and shape inside the egg with the ones on their cards.  The first player to match all their cards to the eggs wins.

Ages 3-7.

Name: Montabaur
Description:
This game is a memory-variant with pictures of the city or region the game is developed for. There are many different editions for about 200 cities or regions in Germany.

Each pair of tiles has a set of corresponding questions on it, where each tiles also gives the answer to the other one.
This way, several trivia-games can be played. Two special dice are included.

The rules describe 7 different way of plays.

Name: Monopoly: Reading
Description: An edition of the commercially successful board game, Monopoly. This edition takes in the English town of Reading. Popular and well known landmarks are for sale including the Madejski Stadium, the Abbey Ruins and The Oracle shopping centre. Local companies and organisations logos feature prominently on the gameboard.

Name: Kaart tennis
Description:
At first sight this "card tennis" game resembles the game Tennis ( http://boardgamegeek.com/game/2841 ) a lot. On close examination, however, there are differences which will be discussed underneath.
First of all it should be noted that the (c) from this game is 1973: two years before Tennis was released! Further, on the box it says (literal translation) "The first and only cardgame on the world based on tennis". The box furthermore states that  the game was issued on occasion of the 75th year of the Dutch Tennis Association. However, a publisher cannot be found on box, or on rule sheets. Based on these data I do believe that this was the predecessor of Tennis.
Differences with Tennis: a) In this game there is no 'ball' nor a pawn (you just move the stack of played cards to the correct position). b) Cards are strictly for either backhand or forehand strokes (indicated with either B or F). c) There are more rules of which card may be played on what card (eg. smash may only following a lob).

Name: Dungeon Escape
Description:
Be the first to collect all the treasures and escape from the dungeon.

Dungeon Escape is a roll and move, dungeon crawl themed game for children ages 7 and up. Move your two children through the maze while avoiding the guards, who will send a player's piece back to the keep. Before a player's piece can exit the dungeon it must land on each of the four marked treasure spaces - Sword, Jewel, Book of Spells, and Key - and collect the corresponding treasures.

Name: Shieldwall
Description:
The game takes its theme from the formation of the Saxon Shieldwall in an abstract form. The pieces reflect this being resin cast representations of stylized Norman and Saxon Infantry.
  The objective of Shieldwall is to capture positions to the rear of the opponent's flanks. Offensive pieces can only attack in pairs and the defending pieces can be formed into stronger units called Shieldwalls.
 The Designer claims that the rules are easy to learn yet the depth of strategy belies its apparent simplicity.

Name: The Game of the Wizard of Oz
Description:
A roll and move game in which players move counters from different initial positions: Dorothy starts in Kansas, the other players in positions ahead of her (Scarecrow, Tin Man, and Lion, in that order.)  The point of the game is to reach the Witch's Castle and then return to the Emerald City.

Similar in design and mechanics to the game Kentucky Derby (1938), and of typical quality of other Whitman Publishing games (paper boards, flimsy boxes, and punch-out paper pawns of other games) it looks as if Whitman didn't spend a lot on the construction of their games, apparently blowing all their budget on the purchase of the character license.

The game contains:

Linen paper game board 
1 dice
4 wooden markers
Two part box with color pictorial cover (measuring 7"x13"x1")

The featured art, though crude, is apparently inspired by the MGM Wizard Of Oz movie.

Name: Block the Clock
Description:
Look out...here comes the runaway clock!

Players must arrange the tiles and create a "track" for the oncoming clock before the alarm goes off and it's too late!

The clock has speed levels for players who dare to rev up the frantic fun in this family game of split second action.

A cross between a sliding 15 puzzle and a pipeline game.

Name: Robber Barons of the Gilded Age
Description: Some superficial similarities to Monopoly such as Board shape and pawn movement. Players build up Wealth and Economic Resources. However to win, you have to have the best Legacy, which means you must convert some of that wealth into philanthropy before the game ends. Monopolies are based on 20 different Industries including Oil, Banking, Railroads, Steel, etc.  Players can own holdings within the same space. Not complex but it does offer lots of period flavor. A complete copy of the rules are available for free at: http://www.angelfire.com/games2/warpspawn/RBGA.html

Name: Donner Knispel
Description:
Donner Knispel is very much like Pachisi, but instead of dice rolling, movement is done by playing cards. Card have values and special abilities, what makes the game much more tactical than Pachisi.

With 4 players it is a partner game and your partner´s pieces can be moved with your own cards.

The game is set in the children's fantasy world of Donner Knispel.

Home Page: http://www.myfleat.com/

Name: Dick Tracy Crime Stopper
Description:
Twenty clue slides are randomly placed in the slots on the gameboard. One of the eight criminal portraits is chosen secretly and placed inside the gameboard. The portrait is now hidden by the clue slides.

Each player, in turn, spins the spinner. The spinner will tell the player which two clues may be removed from the gameboard. The player may then guess which of the eight portraits is concealed by the slides by pressing the appropriate button on the gameboard. If the word "guilty" lights up, then the player has solved the mystery and won the game.

The game uses one "D" battery and a standard flashlight's bulb.

Name: Jagabongo
Description:
From the Box:

A new intergenerational board game for family and friends.  A game of luck, chance and strategy.  Can be played in combinations of two, four or eight players.  The object of the game is to fill your chosen colored areas, and to collect opponent's Jabongs.

Contains two Jagabongo boards, 64 Colored Jabongs and 3 Jates, one rule card and one bag.

Age 7+

Name: Djurens fantastiska värld
Description:
Swedish trivia game about animals (The Fantastic World of Animals). On their turn, players choose their own task for that turn by playing a card from their hand. The categories are charade, picture quiz or one of five different categories of questions, e.g. “Animals in the air”. There are also wild cards. If the player succeeds in her task, she discards her task card. The first player to loose all her cards is the winner. When playing a charade card, the player has one minute to perform the charade. If another player makes the correct guess, then that player may discard any one card from her hand. The player performing the charade may also discard a card because the charade was a success.

8 years and up

Name: Tummenspelet
Description:
Children´s game featuring Tummen (The Thumb), the character from the books of Inger Sandberg. Players roll the die and pick pieces from the box. Pieces have different colors on either end, e.g. yellow/blue pieces, red/green pieces. Each player is trying to make the longest row by connecting ends of the same color. If the die shows the Tummen side the player make take any piece, even from an opponent. This is where the puppets are used: The puppet is put on the player´s thumb and pointed at the piece the player wants. Longest row of pieces wins.

Contents:
49 puzzle pieces
Die w/ labels
4 thumb puppets
Rules

4 years and up

Name: I Mille
Description: Game about the Mille's Sicilian campaign, the first campaign of Garibaldi against the Regno delle Due Sicilie. The game has 1 map, 107 counters and rules.

Name: Travel Time Spinner Game
Description: Travel Time is a car themed spin-and-move game given as a toy with meal by Ruby's Diners.  Players move their car down a twisty road, following the instructions on the spaces.  Completely random and similar to Snakes and Ladders, though thankfully shorter.

Name: Pettson och Findus födelsedagsspel
Description:
Swedish children´s game featuring the characters Pettson and his cat Findus. Players help them make a birthday cake and celebrate. They roll the die and collect chits featuring parts of the cake. If you get a chit with a muckla (the small  ever present creatures from the books) you must give away a birthday present to another player. The first player to have a complete cake with candles, and who has received 2 birthday gifts, is the winner.

Contents:

Gameboard
colored die
42 small chits
48 big chits
Cloth bag
Rules

Name: Abeltje het spel
Description:
Game released in honor of the Dutch movie Abeltje (personal name of an elevator boy). On its turn the movie was based on a children's book by a famous Dutch writer: Annie M.G. Schmidt.

The game itself is a simple roll-and-move system, where some spots have a special meaning, sometimes requiring trivia questions about the movie.

Land on an elevator to move one floor up. Reach the top floor to win the game.

Name: Tour de france
Description:
Yet another very simple TdF game, with a (more-or-less) 3D-board. No date provided, but must be somewhere in the sixties (after the Dutch Jan Janssen won the Tour in '68?). Distributed by a large Dutch warehouse chain.

Use the spinner to determine the number of spots to move forward. Landing on 20 is (for some reason) mandatory to proceed.

This game was released in the Netherlands by Hema and in Germany by Multiplay.

Name: The Kama Sutra Game
Description:
From the back of the game:

For more than a thousand years Kama Sutra has been a guide for lovers of all ages. We have interpreted this great work and offer it to a couple as an interactive game experience.

The Kama Sutra Game™ offers lovers the opportunity to explore the sensual and sexual aspects of their body, mind, and spirit on the journey to experiencing ecstasy.

Object of the Game
- To have fun developing a deeper understanding of what you and your lover like and want in your intimate relationship.

- To engage in an extended session of lovemaking that builds on anticipation, creativity, adventure, and a progression of physical intimacy.

- To expand your sensory awareness through activities using sight, hearing, taste, smell, and... touch.

Game Play
Rolling the die and moving your game pieces, each of you will travel a different path. During the game, the two of you will be communicating, sharing, and participating in a multitude of pleasurable activities and accumulating "Sexual Position" cards. These cards will be played to complete your "journey to ecstasy."

Included in the game:
A playing board, 56 activity and position cards, a die, 2 playing pieces, and instructions.

A Journey to Ecstasy awaits you!

Name: Vi i femman
Description:
Themed on a Swedish TV-quiz for school kids, this game pits 2-4 players or teams against each other. Players answer questions and perform tricky tasks with a time limit. Score markers are moved on a track, and some spaces on the track will trigger a die roll that decides whether players score positive or negative points. This adds a considerable random element.

Contents:
Scoring track
4 pawns
4 White boards
4 pencils and erasers
330 cards
10 topic cards
10 topic markers
Die
Timer
4 puzzles
1 plastic stand

10 years and up

Name: Svensson frågar och Svensson svarar
Description:
The name Svensson is Sweden´s equivalent to Smith, and the title means Svensson asks, Svenssons answers. In this game players earn points by answering trivia questions but also by correctly guessing how many Swedes (in %) have correctly answered the same question on www.vetgirig.nu. People have also submitted questions for the game on the website.

Contents:
Gameboard
3 decks of cards
4 pawns
1 notepad
Rules

14 years and up

Name: Pilare
Description:
Pilare is a board game designed by the Basque game author Jorge Gómez Arrausi. It won a Proxime Accessit award in the Concurs de Creació de Jocs de Tona, 2005 ("Games Creation Contest of Tona").

Pilare is a stacking game in which pieces are moved in a way that resembles the sowing in Kalah games.

Name: Labans spökspel
Description:
Swedish children´s game featuring spöket Laban (Little ghost Godfrey) from the books by Inger and Lasse Sandberg. The friendly ghost must practice some ghostly sounds. Players move around the board, representing the castle, and collect and imitate various sounds. The winner is the player who is the first to reach the Ghost Room and make the Great Ghostly Bawl.

Contents:
26 sound markers with drawings of cats, owls, cars etc.
4 key markers
4 pawns with plastic stands
Die
Rules

Name: The Fall of Bataan
Description: The Fall of Bataan is a two-player game of the American defense of the Bataan Peninsula against the Japanese in 1942. The mapsheet shows the major portion of the Bataan peninsula and the island of Corregidor. The game lasts 10 turns; at the end victory is evaluated based on the number of American units left on the map.

Name: Les Ribauds
Description:
Goal of this game is to become the richest and the Ribaud with most influence in the city. "Ribaud" is an ancient French word which describes a person who likes luxury and extravagance.
You lead a team of crooks which you assign missions to. Each round consists of about 10 phases:
- Draw of a Season Card
- Liberation or execution of arrested team members
- Purchase of Event cards
- Announcement of a "big coup" and negotiation between players
- Secret placement of playing pieces
- Intervention of the police
- Taking back of playing pieces
- Solution of the "big coups"
- Income of players
- Occupation of streets  (and new turn)

After 8 rounds the grand winner is determined.

Name: Kauf bei Mir
Description:
From the promotional packaging inside of Zitadelle, viewable in Image 138790.

We need bread, meat, salt, fruit, dishes, and many more things for our household.  We can find these wares in five stores, or we can buy them in the countryside.  A new game that combines a lotto game with the ideals of a dice game.

Name: Teufelsrad
Description:
From the promotional packaging inside of Zitadelle, viewable in Image 138790.

An interesting and varied board game.  Like in the game Halma, players must get their pieces into an opposite field.  However, the way to get there is over a turntable that one is allowed to turn one quarter, so long as there is another piece in the goal.  That is how the fortune of the party will most change.

Game rules:

This game can be played with up to 4 players.
Each player gets 10 meeples, of which 6 are 
to be moved into the opposite destination spaces 
of the same color.

The starting player is determined by chance.
The meeples can jump over other meeples of the same 
or any other color to get to the destination 
spaces (jumping is done like in the Halma game).

Every time a player gets one of his meeples on a 
destination space, the turntable gets turned a quarter
turn to the right.

This provides for variety in the gameplay, because 
every turn changes the position of the meeples 
for every player.

The winner is the player, who is the first to get 6
meeples on the destination spaces.

The 4 remaining meeples are without importance for the
outcome of the game.


Note: This game is played without a die.

Name: Jugandoconpalabras
Description:
A bilingual word game that uses a game board representing various rooms in a middle school.

The goal is to be the first player to complete proper Spanish sentences in each of eight rooms.

The objectives of this board game are twofold:

1. To teach bilingual students proper Spanish sentence structure.

2. The game also introduces students to the challenges they will face upon entering middle school.

Name: Scarney Dice
Description:
The Scarney Dice set includes 5 special Scarney dice(each d6 contains a 1,3,4,6 and "dead" on 2 opposite sides), a dice cup, chips and 80 page rule book describing more than 40 different dice games that may be played with these dice.

Some of the games include:

Scarney Put and Take Dice
Scarney Duplicate Jackpots
Scarney 21 Up and Down

Name: Poor Bloody Infantry: Company Level Combat in WW2
Description:
Poor Bloody Infantry 2006 is an updated version of the previous game PBI II: 15mm Scale Company Actions of World War 2 by the Rules For The Common Man team.

A miniatures game of World War 2 company level combat, PBI is designed to allow fast playing games that finish in about an hour. PBI uses a terrain map made from grid squares to address the old miniatures game problems of micro measuring and determining angles and line of sight.
Army lists are provided that span all the major countries involved and several of the minor ones over the course of the war.

PBI uses a new recon system that is substantially different than the old one, and much faster to apply. Other changes have streamlined gameplay or cleaned up rules that were somewhat confusing in the previous edition.
Families: Series: Poor Bloody Infantry – WWII Miniature Rules (Peter Pig)

Name: AK47 Supplement
Description: This is a supplement to the AK47 Republic miniature wargames rules providing extensions to the standard rules (cavalry, off table artillery, ambush, collateral, victory conditions, APCs, unarmed militia, night actions, minefields, boats and AA) along with rules for using AK47 for the war in Lebanon and Africa in the 1990s.

Name: X Factor
Description:
Magnetic based board game from the makers of Magz magnetic construction sets.

Each player has a set of Magnetic X tiles. Each tile has different symbols on its sides (hearts, spades, clubs and diamonds).  The timer is started and players race to add tiles to the board, making sure the symbols match.  Tiles can be added either 2 dimension or in 3D.

Name: Scar-Nee and IQ Solitaire
Description:
Scar-Nee and i-Q Solitaire (styled that way on the board) are two distinct abstract strategy games for one to four players, marketed together and using identical equipment.  Similar to Teeko but played on a 4x4 board and using 16 discs (4 different colors each numbered with pips 1 through 4).
It is likely that Scar-Nee is the same game or a direct forerunner of Scarney, and quite possible that i-Q Solitaire is also an ancestor of the solitaire versions of Scarney described in the latter's rule book.

Name: Quadroschach
Description: Chess variant for 2 players (using a bigger board), 3 players (2 vs. 1) or 4 players (teams or individual)

Name: Just Say No! Game
Description:
The object  is to be the first player to unlock the Just Say No! Castle with a golden key. Players earn keys by answering a question on a card. There are no right or wrong answers. For example, "How would you say No if someone tried to give you a pill? Or "What does crack look like?" 
Game was endorsed by the National Just Say No! Foundation, a Nancy Reagan thing.

Name: WooHiiWooHaha
Description: The goal of this game is to build a pyramid of monkeys. There are three types of monkeys and all three types come in three colors. Per turn you can only build your pyramid in one color. When building the other players only see the back of each monkey, so they don't know the constitution of other players' pyramids. The only way to find out is to attack! And attacking is also necessary to keep other players from finishing their pyramids. Finishing your pyramid is a true feat of bananalympics.

Name: The International Pro-Am Sailboard Game
Description: Designed and published by the sailboarding community in 1988, Pro-Am pits players (sailboarders) against each other as they race around the board collecting sponsorships, forging a career, and testing their knowledge on sailboarding. The game can be played on three different levels, from the experienced sail boarder down to the first timers and non-sailboarders who play on the 'Learner' level. Nicely outfitted with plenty of sponsorship options, career directions, and 'sailboards' pieces, the game delves deep into the world of sailboard racing.

Name: Today with Dave Garroway
Description:
Simple spin-and-move game distinguished only by presentation. The pawns are lead figures designed to resemble television cameras. The backdrop to the gameboard has pop-up figures giving the gameboard a 3-D effect. The game comes with a xylophone that must be played or the participant who misses the cue is penalized. The first to reach the finish space is the winner.

An unusual place on the GameBoard is the Station Break Area which is represented by clock symbols. If you land on or pass over one of these Station Breaks you must ring the TIME SIGNAL TONES to properly identify the network. If you fail to do so you must move your camera back 15 spaces.

Name: Jan Murray's Treasure Hunt
Description:
Each player will act as quizmaster for another player so everyone can compete.  A random category for each round is determined by the Bid Wheel. Every correct answer earns the player fifty dollars. A round consists of four questions for each player. The winner of round chooses a card which represents a treasure chest and its treasure. The player also spins the Bid Wheel. The player may now choose between the known amount on the Bid Wheel (range: $250 to $2000) or take whatever happens to be on the card (range: $0 to $25,000)

The player who chooses and keeps the $25,000 treasure chest card is the immediate winner. Otherwise, the game goes the full four rounds. The winner is the person who has the most money after four rounds of play.

The game is based on a popular television series of the fifties.

Name: Dave Garroway's Today Game
Description:
The players take on the role of television show producer vying to book the best guests for television’s “The Today Show”. The deck is divided into four suits. Each suit represents a category of guest. Each suit has cards valued one through twelve; one being the greatest value and twelve having the least value. There are also four wild cards, valued at thirteen, to bring the total number of cards in the deck to fifty-two.

All players place their pawns on the start space. Each player chooses a card secretly. All players reveal their chosen cards simultaneously. The player who played the highest valued card gets to advance one’s own pawn the number of spaces equal to value of the winning card. The rules do not state what happens if two or more players tie. If two or more players play wild cards, there is no winner and the hand is replayed.

Certain spaces on the track assign a player who happens to land on them a personal trump suit. This trump stays in effect until the player moves on.

The hand is over when someone lands on the “Off the Air” space at the end of the track. The value of the cards remaining in the hand of the players is totaled and added to the score of the player who ended the round. All players receive the value of the cards in tricks each has taken. The first player to score five hundred points is the winner.

Name: Future Tank
Description:
From the back of the rule book:

FUTURE TANK

Future tank is a two-player board game pitting players against each other with tank armies of their own choosing!

Players have four different types of tanks to choose from in which to build their armies:

1) Fast-Assault Tanks: Quick, highly maneuverable and able to outflank any other tank with cutting precision.

2) Light-Assault Tanks: Fast, but more heavily armored and more heavily weaponed. It can pack a solid punch.

3) Heavy-Assault Tanks: Slow, but carry the biggest gun!

4) Missile Tanks: Slow and heavily armored. Able to kill from a distance.

Rules are easy-to-read and play-action can let you start blasting away in the first turn! Terrain features are optional and six scenarios are included.

Average Play Time: 20-40 Minutes."

Played on a chess board, this games uses either the photocopied "counters" from the book, or minis of your choosing. You will also need a D4, D6, D8 and D12. A basic move and attack format. Lighter moves further and heaver shoots further. Each tank has a diagram showing its armor amounts (think SFB shields) and has ratings for movement, firing ranges and weapon damage.

Name: UnStack
Description: UnStack was created by Professor João Pedro Neto, Lisbon (Portugal), in 2001. It is a stacking game in which counters are distributed in a way that resembles the "sowing" in Kalah games.

Name: The $64,000 Question
Description:
THE $64,000 QUESTION is a board game based on the UK version of the TV Game Show.  The aim of the game is to work along a question path answering questions and enter 'the isolator' to answer the $64,000 question.  The first player to get the $64,000 question correct is the winner.

Questions are categorized into 10 subject areas which are selected by the roll of a 10 sided die.  An additional category is provided when playing with younger players.

Name: Poetic Justice
Description:
From the box:

"POETIC JUSTICE" is the super-duper, pretty-witty game where one word leads to another.  All you need is a dash of logic and a flash of inspiration to uncover the poetic solutions.

Poetic Cards consist of cleverly worked clues which are solved with rhyming couplets and a splash of humor!

Depending on where you land on the board you may have to play solo, challenge another player or join everyone else in this game of reason and rhyme."

Name: Noel's House Party
Description:
NOEL'S HOUSE PARTY is a board game spin-off from the UK's TV Show of the same name.  It involves recreations of the main features of the show.

From the box:

"Round and around Crinkley Bottom you go... in for the Music Game .... down the cellar for 'Wait till I get you home'.  But who's that at the door? - better go and find out, oh no! you've landed in the grunge tank - or worse still you've to face the NTV talent test.

This new and exiting family game is fast-paced and action packed and features a fully working three-dimensional 'Grad a Grand' booth complete with miniature money".

The aim of the game is to collect the most money by moving around the board and performing a variety of actions based on the draw of a card:

NTV - act out the instructions on the card.
KNOCK KNOCK - Guess the identity of someone from clues on the card.
WAIT TILL I GET YOU HOME! - Guessing what answer another player will give to a question.
MUSIC GAME - Music based trivia or performance card.

Other spaces require you to spin again, miss a turn or take possion of the Gotcha! (allowing you to score double points whilst you have it).

Name: Risks and Rhymes
Description:
Purple Ronnie's Groovy Game of RISKS AND RHYMES is an adult game involving moving around a board, making up poems, acting and drinking (preferably alcoholic beverages)

There are two decks of cards:
the first represents different character types (i.e.slob, sex goddess, mummy's boy ...)
the second comprises risks and rhymes.  Risk cards involve acting out whatever is written on the card.  The rhyme cards contain a short poem to which the final line needs to be added.

Players move round the board as per the roll of a die.  The space they land on determines what action they need to perform:
- Borrow a character card from another player
- Miss a turn
- take a Risk and Rhymes card for themselves or another player
- Roll again
- Give a character card to another player

All risks and rhymes must be performed in the style of the character card in play at the time with a successful performance resulting in winning of that character card.  The winner is the player who, at the end of the game, has collected the most character cards.

Name: Your First Impression
Description:
The players must deduce which of the six given historical figures is the correct one. The players choose and ask the questions on the cards given to them while the quizmaster responds according to the answer key. The player who gives the correct answer scores points depending on how many questions were asked by the players. The first to score one hundred points is the winner.

The game is loosely based on a television series designed by Monty Hall of Let’s Make a Deal fame. Mr. Hall’s name is misspelled on the box lid.

Name: Diamino Chinois
Description:
Word game similar to Diamino, by the same publisher, except that it uses hexagonal tiles instead of square ones. Unlike Diamino, tiles do not have point values
Like Diamino, it has some tiles with a red logo or design on it.

Name: Circulus
Description:
Four "snakes" consisting of 12 tokens each try to conquer numbered spaces on the game board. A dice rolling game for up to four players. 
Roll the dice and move your snake by placing same number of pieces as rolled from the end of your snake in front of it. Try to surround a circle with your snake and score by placing a snake piece inside the surrounded circle. So your snake becomes shorter and you will have less pieces to surround the next circles.

Name: Diamantenfieber
Description: A fishing game with semi-precious stones. Players hide  magnetic stones in 12 heaps of non-magnetic stones, then try to fish out as many magnetic stones from all heaps as they can.

Name: Tank Battles in Miniature 1: A wargamers' guide to the Western Desert Campaign 1940-1942
Description:
subtitle - A wargamers' guide to the Western Desert Campaign 1940-1942

Book including miniatures rules for wargames in the North African desert during WW2.

From the publisher's description;

...contents include a summary of the actual campaign, illustrated with numerous maps, plus technical specifications for the vehicles, tanks, guns and aircraft used.  Further chapters cover terrain, communications, visibility, navigation, firing tank and anti-tank guns, 'brewing up', air operations, the Long Range Desert Group, minefields and supply.  There are also appendices on British and Axis armored formations, recognition silhouettes, armor penetration tables and the construction of various wargaming aids.
Families: Series: Tank Battles in Miniature (Patrick Stephens Limited)

Name: Discovering Wargames
Description:
Small paperback book serving as an introduction to miniatures wargaming and also containing rules for use from the ancient period up to the American Civil War (1 rule set for the whole lot !)

Rules are based on rolling a one die for each group of six figures when shooting, or counting heads and multiplying by a die roll in melee.  Also includes rules for differing formations and for morale.

Name: Savage Worlds: Tour of Darkness
Description:
Savage Worlds Weird Wars: Vietnam setting covering both the French and American wars.

From the Pinnacle website:

Welcome to the jungle, baby! Now you're gonna die!

If it bleeds …you can kill it. Or so they say.

But who really knows? Who knows what horrors lurk in the jungles of “the ‘Nam?” There are rumors, of course, but there are even more rumors of squads—even whole companies—just disappearing into the bush. But the brass says nothing. And the body bags just keep coming.

You know how bad the booby traps and ambushes are, but have you ever wondered what dark Gods those forgotten jungle temples were built for? Or what makes those bizarre crying sounds in the remote highlands, far away from any villages? Or why even the locals fear the so-called “cannibalistic” mountain tribes?

Lock and load your M-16, feed a belt into your M-60, and load another round in your Thumper, soldiers.

You’re going to war. Weird War.

Tour of Darkness is the Weird Wars: Vietnam game setting. It requires the Savage Worlds rules to play.

Tour of Darkness includes rules for Sanity, Terror, new Edges and Hindrances, and complete Plot Point Campaigns for both the American and French tours in Vietnam.

Expands:

    Savage Worlds

Name: Joseph and His Coat of Many Colors
Description:
Joseph And His Coat Of Many Colors is a variation on the popular game of UNO with uniquely illustrated cards depicting the biblical character of Joseph wearing his colored coats.  Players are trying to empty their hands of cards by playing them to a common pile, matching cards by color, number, or action.  The deck is made up of 4 sets of differently colored cards with numbers from 1 to 6.  There are also Miracle cards (wild cards), cards that cause the next player to pick up 1 or 2 cards, and Skip cards.

Note: This game is different from UNO in the following ways:
- Instead of "Draw 4 wild cards", this game contains some "Draw 1" cards.  This is in addition to the "Draw 2 cards" both games have.
- This game has only a 35-card deck.
- When a person has only one card left in their hand, they are to call out "Joseph".

Name: 18MY
Description:
An 18XX game series based on the railroad development in Malaya (Malaysia before Independence). It is set in 1885, when the first railroads were built to transport cargo between the Ports.

Special rules include:

a) The map includes part of Southern Siam (Thailand).
b) A Siam Pass is up for auction after the Private Companies Auction but before the Stock buying round (on the first turn). Siam Pass is then auctioned out again when the first '3' train and '5' train is bought. The holder of the Siam Pass allow one of his/her Corporation to run trains into Siam without rolling the 'Train Hijack' die. (See Below) 
c) Train Hijack mechanics. Where, while running trains into Siam, the corporation president must roll a die. On the roll of 4,5 or 6, the train is hijacked and no revenues are generated from that train. The train card is then flipped over and cannot be used until after the next stock round.

Name: High School Musical DVD Game
Description:
From bestbuy.com summary:

"High school is a stage and here's your chance to be a part of the show. Jump into the hit Disney Channel movie High School Musical with this fun, interactive DVD game. Enjoy video clips, original outtakes and all of the songs and dances you love from the movie.

Compete against your friends in four challenging categories: Outtakes, Song, Dance and Relationship. The first player to make his or her way around the school for the final call back audition is the winner. Prove you have what it takes to make it in high school. After all, it really is just a song and a dance. "

Name: Disaster!
Description:
DISASTER! is for ages 8 and up, 2 to 4 players with an average playing time 15 - 30 minutes.
Learn about natural disasters and how they affect the U.S, including how scientists rank the strengths of the different disasters. Learn which geographic areas are at risk and how the seasons affect a disaster's occurrence. Tornadoes, earthquakes, hurricanes, floods, wildfires... are just a few of the disasters that you'll face in this game. Game includes: Deck of 59 full color board Disaster & Defense playing cards, full-color game board featuring map of US, 15 color territory marker pieces.

Each card contains facts and information about specific historical disasters. In DISASTER!, you want to control territories of the US that are worth different points. You gain territories by playing disaster cards against your opponent's territories, like a hurricane against Florida. But your opponent might have a defense... like The National Hurricane Center... To block you. Each game last 16 turns, with each turn a different season. Many disasters can only be played during certain seasons. At end of the last turn , add up your points for the territories you control, the player with the highest points wins!

Name: Confucianism and the Succession Crisis of the Wanli Emperor, 1587
Description:
From Description:

Confucianism and the Succession Crisis of the Wanli Emperor, 1587 seeks to introduce undergraduate students to the suppleness and power of Confucian thought as applied to issues of governance during the Ming dynasty.  The game is set in the Hanlin Academy.  Most students are members of the Grand Secretariat of the Hanlin Academy, the body of top-ranking graduates of the civil service examination who serve as advisers to the Wanli emperor.  Some Grand Secretaries are Confucian "purists,” who hold that tradition obliges the emperor to name his first-born son as successor; others, in support of the most senior of the Grand Secretaries, maintain that it is within the emperor’s right to choose his successor; and still others, as they decide this matter among many issues confronting the empire, continue to scrutinize the teachings of Confucianism for guidance.  The game unfolds amidst the secrecy and intrigue within the walls of the Forbidden City, as scholars struggle to apply Confucian precepts to a dynasty in peril.

Name: Meatgrinder: Battle of Xuan Loc 1975
Description:
This is a redux to Perry Moore's original game. Defiance: The Battle of Xuan Loc (Swedish Games).

Covers the Battle of Xuan Loc April 1975. Basically ARVN defenders backed up by air power vs. hordes of NVA with tanks and heavy artillery. This was the last stand of the South Vietnamese Army against all odds (which is why it may become an ATO issue game). The ARVN 18th division armed with M-48 Tanks and Cluster bombs conduct themselves in a heroic manner, so much so, that it becomes noticed by the outside world media press. The battle involved large amounts of aircraft and tanks. The ARVN defiant stand stunned the three NVA Divisions assigned to take the town. The two sides clashed for 10 days-it became a battle of honor! This game is a much improved version of Perry's earlier 1982 game.

System is similar to Perry Moore's Nanawa: Verdun in the Chaco War, July 1933.

Name: Sì, Oscuro Signore! 2: L'alba degli eroi
Description:
You go far beyond the oldest place, to serve the Dark Overlord. You faced the worst perils to put your hands on the magician's hat. Now the Genius of Evil has new quests for you, and you'll have to go even beyond, through dimensions, getting new treasures and facing new perils. Maybe even the Death herself.
But the real peril will be to face the Rigor Mortis, if you'll fail another time.

"Sì, Oscuro Signore! 2 - L'alba degli eroi" it's the first expansion for Aye, Dark Overlord! The Red Box also known as "Aye, Dark Overlord", and it'll bring you new cards with places to explore, people to meet and treasures to retrieve. And that's not all... You, the goblins, will have new actions to make even more difficult your fellow party to escape the right Wrath of the Dark Overlord.

Until now, it was only a joke.
